Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Can Predation Risk Limit Small Mammal Seed Predation in Novel Winter Habitats?
Award.AbstractNarration:
In northern forests, many plants and animals live at the interface between the snow and soil. In recent decades snowfall has declined across many parts of the northern United States and this decline is expected to continue into the future. This study focuses on how small mammals that live at the interface between the snow and the soil respond to the loss of this habitat. While deep snow allows small mammals, such as mice or voles, to hide from predators, these animals may benefit from leaving snow covered areas to search for food (seeds and seedlings). This study will remove snow in a small area to determine whether less snow leads small mammals to spend more time foraging and being susceptible to predators. Cameras will be used to record changes in the behavior of the small mammals. Seeds and seedlings will be monitored to determine how the changes in mammal behavior influence their survival. Understanding conditions that promote small mammal activity in areas with little snow could help in predicting seedling survival in future decades, ultimately leading to more effective forest management strategies. This study will support the training of a graduate and undergraduate student and will provide opportunities for outreach with K-12 students and with the general public.

This research examines the importance of snow depth and predation risk on small mammal activity and seed predation in a northern temperate forest. The researchers will conduct an experiment that manipulates the predation refuge provided by the interface between the soil and snow (subnivium), and an alternative predation refuge (woody debris) from which most snow has been removed. Using a recently described technique, motion-sensor infrared cameras will be placed in each treatment combination to compare small mammal activity in areas with deep snow and shallow snow. Cameras will be focused on trays containing seeds and seedlings of four native tree species, allowing researchers to quantify how changes in small mammal activity can influence the relative survival rates of the plant species they consume. By combining camera traps in the subnivium with a seed removal assay, researchers will also be able to monitor the small mammal species consuming seeds. This research will help clarify the trade-offs small mammals face between foraging efficiency and predation risk during winter, providing a more thorough understanding of how environmental context might alter the relationship between snow depth, and small mammals and the seeds they consume.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change is rapidly reshaping ecosystems across the country. Small mammals (e.g., rodents) play a critical role in many ecosystems, providing an important source of prey to sustain predators, while also limiting plant regeneration by consuming seeds or seedlings. There is therefore an urgent need to understand how climate change will affect small mammal communities, but small mammal responses to climate change will likely vary across the US. In northern temperate forests, a commonly overlooked consequence of climate change is that even small increases in winter temperatures can cause dramatic decreases in snowfall and snow accumulation. Many small mammals rely on deep snow to insulate them from cold temperatures and provide cover to avoid predators. In a warmer winter with reduced snow, small mammals may face more exposure to colder temperatures and predators. However, deep snow can also make foraging more difficult for small mammals, as snow restricts access to important food items, such as seeds. Understanding how climate change will reshape small mammal communities will therefore require a deeper understanding of how these animals use snow as habitat during winter.

In order to better understand the importance of snow for small mammals, we coupled a new approach to monitoring small mammal winter activity with an experiment that manipulated the risk of predation during winter. Using motion-activated cameras deployed under the snow, we obtained unprecedented observations of small mammals in their winter habitat. Two small-mammal species accounted for 99% of photographs: white-footed mice (Peromyscus leucopus) and southern red-backed voles (Myodes gapperi). White-footed mice, which are thought to be exclusively nocturnal, were almost always photographed during the day. This switch to daytime activity minimized the exposure of mice to extreme cold temperatures at night. Voles showed no clear activity pattern, but avoided activity entirely on cold days. We then added seeds of five native tree species (balsam fir, sugar maple, red maple, red oak, red pine) to a series of plots that varied in snow cover (experimentally removed or not removed) and woody debris addition, which provides important cover for small mammals. We predicted that removing snow would increase the number of seeds consumed by small mammals if woody debris replaced the cover provided by snow, but that removing snow would decrease the number of seeds consumed by small mammals in the absence of an alternative refuge from predators. Removing snow increased the number of balsam fir and sugar maple seeds consumed by small mammals, but woody debris had either no effect (sugar maple) or decreased the number of seeds consumed (balsam fir). Three species (red maple, red oak, red pine) showed no consistent response to the snow removal and woody debris treatments.

Together, these results show that climate change might have a strong effect on the behavior of small mammals during winter. Without snow cover, white-footed mice may not be able to alter the timing of their activity. However, nocturnal activity has been assumed to be a fixed characteristic of white-footed mice, and future research will be needed to explore the conditions responsible for switches between daytime and nocturnal activity, in this and other species. We also found evidence that reduced snowfall may amplify the number of seeds consumed by small mammals, which can limit forest regeneration. This effect may not be universal, though, as only balsam fir and sugar maple responded to our snow removal treatments. While we predicted that woody debris would increase the number of seeds consumed by small mammals, we observed the opposite. This may be because predators of small mammals that are well-adapted to habitats with deep snow (such as fishers or martens) can use woody debris to tunnel under snow. In this case, habitat features that provide safety from predators in the summer may increase vulnerability to predators during winter. Throughout this project, the behavior of small mammals we observed in winter could not be predicted based on studies conducted solely during the summer. This highlights the need to explicitly study how climate change will affect ecosystems during winter.

This project has provided scientific training for one graduate student and two undergraduate students, and led to the development of an undergraduate lecture about the consequences of climate change. These findings also provide two key pieces of information that may help land managers anticipate how northern temperate forests will respond to climate change. First, behavioral changes may provide some small-mammal species with flexibility to adapt to changes in the near future, although more research will be needed to understand the limits of such behavioral changes. Second, as winters continue to warm in the northern United States, managing northern temperate forests to ensure regeneration from seed may require accounting for behavioral changes across the food web.
